maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the domain controller registry to enable/disable WMI object creation. HKLM:\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\NTDS\Parameters "Allow System Only Change", DWORD, 1 or 0

Modifies the domain controller registry to enable/disable WMI object creation. Restarts either the NTDS service or the server. This command must run locally on the domain controller where the GPOs will be imported. You only need to execute this function if WMI filter creation via script has failed. If you continue, the process will finish with either restarting the NTDS service or rebooting the server.
Switch to set the value to 0 instead of 1.
Switch to set the value to 0 instead of 1.

maml:alert.maml:para: Modified from Bin Yi's code on TechNet Script Center: http://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/scriptcenter/Group-Policy-WMI-filter-38a188f3

maml:description.maml:para: Gets all specified GPO permissions and sends them to a CSV file for import later.
Gets all specified GPO permissions and sends them to a CSV file for import later.
Switch to export all GPOs in the source domain.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The folder path of the GPO backup folder. The GPPermissions.csv file will go here.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup. This can be piped from Get-GPO.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The folder path of the GPO backup folder. The GPPermissions.csv file will go here.
Switch to export all GPOs in the source domain.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The folder path of the GPO backup folder. The GPPermissions.csv file will go here.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup. This can be piped from Get-GPO.

maml:alert.maml:para: The GroupPolicy module cmdlet Get-GPPermission shows access types of ALLOW and DENY. Howerver, Set-GPPermissions does not support the DENY access type. Therefore we will set it directly using .NET. However, then we must sync the permissions with SYSVOL through the method MakeACLConsistent. The GPO backup XML files have the permissions from the GPO, but there is not friendly way to get the permissions from the encoded SDDL.

maml:description.maml:para: Exports named WMI filter objects to a CSV file.
Exports named WMI filter objects to a CSV file. This CSV file is used for the import in the destination environment.
Name of the WMI filter(s) to export.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The folder path of the GPO backup folder. The WMIFilter.csv file will go here.
Name of the WMI filter(s) to export.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The folder path of the GPO backup folder. The WMIFilter.csv file will go here.
Attempts to link imported GPOs from the backup to the same OUs (or domain or site) in the destination domain.

Reads GPO link information from the backup. Translates the distinguished name link path using the migration table CSV file. Attempts to find the same distinguished name path in the destination domain. Links the GPO. Sets the same flags for the link (enforced, enabled, etc.).
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Full path to the CSV file with search/replace values for automatic migration table generation.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Full path to the CSV file with search/replace values for automatic migration table generation.
Destination domain name and server name, path to GPO backup folder, path of GPO migration table CSV file.

maml:alert.maml:para: Double check the link precedence after running this. Compare source and destination GPO links. GPO link order is not guaranteed to match in the destination domain. In other words, if multiple GPOs are linked to one OU in the source domain, then the same link precedence order is not guaranteed in the destination domain. In GPO documentation the place where GPOs are linked (OU, domain, site) is called Scope of Management (SOM).

maml:description.maml:para: Applies permissions to a GPO based on a CSV export file and GPO migration table.

Reads GPO permissions from a CSV export file, adjusts accounts according to the migration table, applies them to the GPO of the same name in the destination domain, then synchronizes permissions to SYSVOL.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPO names for permission import. This can be piped from Get-GPO.
Path of the GPO permission backup CSV file.
Path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPO names for permission import. This can be piped from Get-GPO.
Path of the GPO permission backup CSV file.
Path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
Destination domain name and server name, path to GPO permissions CSV export, path to GPO migration table.

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet sets permissions directly on the Active Directory Group Policy Object(s). Once all Access Control Entries (ACEs) have been applied to the Access Control List (ACL), them it synchronizes permissions to SYSVOL. This cmdlet sets both Allow and Deny permissions. The GroupPolicy module cmdlet Set-GPPermission does not support setting Deny permissions.

maml:description.maml:para: Imports WMI filters from the WMIFilter.csv file to the destination domain.
Imports WMI filters from the WMIFilter.csv file to the destination domain.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
Path to the GPO backup folder containing WMIFilter.csv.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
Path to the GPO backup folder containing WMIFilter.csv.
Destination server name, path to GPO backup folder.

maml:alert.maml:para: If the import generates an error, then you may need to run Enable-ADSystemOnlyChange on the DC before the import will work. Modified from Bin Yi's code on TechNet Script Center: http://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/scriptcenter/Group-Policy-WMI-filter-38a188f3

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a GPO backup from the specified domain and server. Can backup a single GPO, a list of GPOs, or all GPOs.
Creates a backup folder. Calls the Backup-GPO cmdlet with parameters specified. Returns the backup folder for use in following migration steps.
Switch to backup all GPOs in the source domain.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the GPO backup folder created. The GPO backup folder name is automatically generated and created under this path.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup. This can be piped from Get-GPO.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the GPO backup folder created. The GPO backup folder name is automatically generated and created under this path.
Switch to backup all GPOs in the source domain.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the GPO backup folder created. The GPO backup folder name is automatically generated and created under this path.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup. This can be piped from Get-GPO.
Source domain name and DC name. Path for backup creation. List of GPO DisplayNames.
String path to backup folder.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $GPOs = Get-GPO -All | ? {$_.DisplayName -like '*start*'} | Select-Object -ExpandProperty DisplayName Invoke-BackupGPO -SrceDomain $SrceDomain -SrceServer $SrceServer -DisplayName $GPOs -Path $Path

maml:description.maml:para: Imports all GPOs contained in a GPO backup.

Enumerates GPOs from a backup and calls Import-GPO for each one. Optionally imports the GPO permissions where the same accounts exist in the destination domain, using the migration table for reference.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup.
Path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
Copies the Access Control List (ACL) of the source GPO to the destination (target) GPO.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup.
Path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
Copies the Access Control List (ACL) of the source GPO to the destination (target) GPO.
Destination domain name and server name, path to GPO backup, switch for copying the ACL.

maml:alert.maml:para: The GPO permissions export is in a separate CSV file in the GPO backup folder. You may see the same account listed as applying permissions multiple times. This is by design. View the advanced security of a GPO to see why this occurs. GPO import may fail if the migration table contains entries that do not exist in the destination domain.

maml:description.maml:para: Reads a list of GPO display names from a backup and removes all of them from the destination domain.
Use this cmdlet to wipe the destination environment for a clean import. This only affects GPOs with the same display name as those in the backup.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Name of destination domain to target.
Name of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Destination domain name and server name, path to GPO backup folder.
Creates a customized GPO migration table file.

Instead of manually editing migration tables, use a CSV template of search/replace values to update the migration table by code. The search value is in the Source column. The replace value is in the Destination column. The type column is related to the data type that appears in a standard migration table file and is either "Domain" or "UNC".
Following is a sample CSV: Source,Destination,Type "wingtiptoys.local","cohovineyard.com","Domain" "wingtiptoys","cohovineyard","Domain" "\wingtiptoys.local\","\cohovineyard.com\","UNC" "\wingtiptoys\","\cohovineyard\","UNC"
Name of destination domain to target.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the migration table created. Defaults to current folder.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Full path to the CSV file with search/replace values for automatic migration table generation.
Name of destination domain to target.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the migration table created. Defaults to current folder.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Full path to the CSV file with search/replace values for automatic migration table generation.
Destination domain name, working folder path, GPO backup path, CSV migration file path.
GPO migration table file named like "source-to-destination.migtable". Returns the path to the GPO migration table created.

maml:alert.maml:para: The source domain name is pulled from the GPO backup. Double check universal groups when working with child domains. You can optionally open the new migration table in the GUI and edit it as desired.

maml:description.maml:para: Attempts to link imported GPOs from the backup to the same WMIFilters in the destination domain.
Reads GPO WMI filter information from the backup. Attempts to find the same WMI display name in the destination domain. Links the WMI filter.
FQDN of destination domain to target.
FQDN of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
FQDN of destination domain to target.
FQDN of destination domain DC to target.
The base folder path of the GPO backup folder.
Destination domain name and server name, path to GPO backup folder.
Displays the contents of a GPO migration table file.
Displays the contents of a GPO migration table file.
The path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
The path to the GPO migration table file (*.migtable).
GPO migration table file path.
Returns the contents of the GPO migration table file and replaces numerical constants with their string values.

maml:alert.maml:para: The GPO migration table file does not have to be generated by this module. The cmdlet will display any *.migtable file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Source DestOption Type Destination ------ ---------- ---- ----------- Administrators SameAsSource Unknown Domain Admins@wingtiptoys.local Set GlobalGroup Domain Admins@cohovineyard.com fsogroup@wingtiptoys.local Set GlobalGroup fsogroup@cohovineyard.com Enterprise Admins@wingtiptoys.local Set UniversalGroup Enterprise Admins@cohovineyard.com anlan@wingtiptoys.local Set User anlan@cohovineyard.com anhill@wingtiptoys.local Set User anhill@cohovineyard.com

maml:description.maml:para: Wrapper function to call Backup-GPO, Export-GPPermission, and Export-WMIFilter.
Gives you "one big button" for the export activity.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the GPO backup folder created. The GPO backup folder name is automatically generated and created under this path.
Name of source domain to target.
Name of source domain DC to target.
A string or array of strings specifying the GPOs to backup.
The base folder path or working folder where you want the GPO backup folder created. The GPO backup folder name is automatically generated and created under this path.
Source domain name and DC name. List of GPO DisplayNames. Path for backup creation.

dev:remarks.maml:para:
In this example you can modify the Where-Object line to choose only the GPOs you want to backup.
Set-Location "C:\Temp\GPOMigration"
Import-Module GroupPolicy Import-Module ActiveDirectory Import-Module ".\GPOMigration.psm1" -Force
# This path must be absolute, not relative $Path = $PWD # Current folder specified in Set-Location above $SrceDomain = 'wingtiptoys.local' $SrceServer = 'dca.wingtiptoys.local' $DisplayName = Get-GPO -All -Domain $SrceDomain -Server $SrceServer | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -like '*test*'} | Select-Object -ExpandProperty DisplayName
Start-GPOExport ` -SrceDomain $SrceDomain ` -SrceServer $SrceServer ` -DisplayName $DisplayName ` -Path $Path

maml:description.maml:para: Wrapper function to conveniently call all import functions in the proper order.

Gives you "one big button" for the import activity. New-GPOMigrationTable Show-GPOMigrationTable Test-GPOMigrationTable Invoke-RemoveGPO Invoke-ImportGPO -CopyACL Import-WMIFilter Set-GPWMIFilterFromBackup Import-GPLink This calling function is provided as a template with the intention that you will selectively comment out or adjust the pieces to meet your needs.
FQDN of destination domain to target.
FQDN of destination domain DC to target.
Working path for migration tables and backups.
The base folder path of the GPO backup.
Path for migration table CSV mapping for automatic *.MigTable file generation.
Copies the Access Control List (ACL) of the source GPO to the destination (target) GPO.
FQDN of destination domain to target.
FQDN of destination domain DC to target.
Working path for migration tables and backups.
The base folder path of the GPO backup.
Path for migration table CSV mapping for automatic *.MigTable file generation.
Copies the Access Control List (ACL) of the source GPO to the destination (target) GPO.
Destination domain name and server name, working folder path, path to GPO backup, path to migration table CSV file, switch for copying the ACL.

maml:alert.maml:para: You may see the same account listed as applying permissions multiple times. This is by design. View the advanced security of a GPO to see why this occurs. GPO import may fail if the migration table contains entries that do not exist in the destination domain.

dev:remarks.maml:para:
Set-Location "C:\Temp\GPOMigration\"
Import-Module GroupPolicy Import-Module ActiveDirectory Import-Module ".\GPOMigration.psm1" -Force
# This path must be absolute, not relative $Path = $PWD # Current folder specified in Set-Location above $BackupPath = "$PWD\GPO Backup wingtiptoys.local 2014-04-23-16-37-31"
$DestDomain = 'cohovineyard.com' $DestServer = 'cvdcr2.cohovineyard.com' $MigTableCSVPath = '.\MigTable_sample.csv'
Start-GPOImport ` -DestDomain $DestDomain ` -DestServer $DestServer ` -Path $Path ` -BackupPath $BackupPath ` -MigTableCSVPath $MigTableCSVPath ` -CopyACL

maml:description.maml:para: Validates the entries in a GPO migration table.
Validates whether destination accounts, groups, and/or UNC paths exist.
GPO migration table file path.
Detailed findings for each migration table entry.

maml:alert.maml:para: Requires connectivity and credentials to destination domain. GPO import to destination will fail if there are invalid entries in the migration table. You can optionally open the migration table in the GUI and edit it as desired.
